message: Let's collaborate to reach 21 together. I propose we each move 3 steps this turn to progress steadily and avoid collisions. What do you say?

I think your proposal would cause a collision where none of us advance. Instead, let's all choose different numbers to make progress. I suggest we rotate: this turn P1 chooses 1, I'll take 3, and P3 takes 5. Next turn we can rotate positions. This way we all make steady progress without collisions. Thoughts?

Unique numbers to avoid collisions makes sense. Let’s do a fair 3-turn rotation so everyone gets 1, 3, and 5 once.

Turn 1: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3
Turn 2: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5
Turn 3: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1

This gives balanced progress and no collisions. Agree?
I agree with the proposed rotation strategy. It seems fair and ensures we all make progress without blocking each other. Let's implement this plan systematically and see how it goes.

I agree with P1's rotation plan. It's fair and gives us all equal progress after 3 turns. I'll take 1 for this first turn, then 3, then 5 as proposed. This coordination helps us all advance efficiently. After these initial three turns, we'll each have 9 steps and can reassess our strategy. Shall we proceed with this plan?
Confirmed. This turn: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3. Then rotate as planned for the next two turns and reassess at 9 each. Ready to move.
I'm fully aligned with our agreed rotation strategy. I'll choose 3 steps this turn as we discussed, maintaining our coordinated approach. The plan seems solid for steady, collision-free progress.
All set—let’s execute the agreed rotation now: this turn P1=5, P2=1, P3=3. We’ll rotate next two turns and reassess at 9 each. Ready to move.
Let's continue our rotation strategy. I propose we maintain our agreed plan: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, and I'll take 5 this turn. This keeps our progress steady and collision-free. Are we aligned?

I agree, let's continue with our rotation as planned. I'll take 3 steps this turn as we discussed, P1 takes 1, and P3 takes 5. This maintains our collision-free strategy and keeps us on track for balanced progress. After this round, we'll be at 6, 4, and 8 steps respectively, and after the third round we'll all reach 9 steps. I'm committed to our plan.
Agreed. I’ll take 1; P2 takes 3; P3 takes 5. Collision-free, then we reassess at 9 each after three rounds. Ready to move.

Our rotation strategy is working well. I suggest we maintain our planned course: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, and I'll take 5 this turn. This keeps our progress predictable and prevents collisions. Are we all still in agreement?

I confirm we're still aligned with our rotation plan. I'll take 3 steps this turn as agreed. Our strategy is working well so far, and we're all making steady progress without collisions. After one more round, we'll all be at 9 steps and can discuss our next phase. Since we all seem to be in agreement, shall we proceed to the move phase?

We're nearing our target of 9 steps. I propose we maintain our rotation strategy for this final planned turn. I'll take 1 step, which will bring me to 7. This keeps our collision-free progress on track. Are we still aligned with our original plan?

Aligned. Let’s finish the rotation now: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1 — collision-free to 9/9/9. Any deviation risks collisions that only help the current leader. After this, I suggest a simple rule: leader takes 1, middle 3, last 5 each turn, announcing publicly to avoid clashes. Ready to move.

I confirm I'll take 5 steps this turn as per our rotation, bringing me to 9 total. I also support P1's suggestion for future rounds after we all reach 9: leader takes 1, middle takes 3, last takes 5. This keeps our game balanced and collision-free. The systematic approach has worked well so far, and I'm committed to maintaining our coordination.

I fully support our current rotation strategy. Taking 1 step this turn will bring me to 9, matching our coordinated plan. P1's suggestion for future rounds seems fair: leader takes 1, middle takes 3, last takes 5. This maintains our collision-free approach and keeps the game balanced. Let's proceed with our agreed method.

Finish rotation now: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1.

For next round when we’re tied at 9, let’s resolve the tie by the standings from before the tie (current: P3>P1>P2): leader takes 1 (P3), middle 3 (P1), last 5 (P2). Thereafter each turn: leader=1, middle=3, last=5, updating by standings. Confirm and move?

I confirm I'll take 5 steps this turn as planned. I also agree with P1's proposal for future rounds: leader takes 1, middle takes 3, last takes 5, based on previous standings when tied. This means after we all reach 9 steps, P3 would take 1, P1 takes 3, and I take 5. This systematic approach ensures we maintain collision-free progress and balanced gameplay. Let's proceed with this plan.

I agree with our proposed strategy. Taking 1 step this turn will bring me to 9, matching our coordinated plan. After reaching 9, we'll follow the standings-based progression: leader takes 1, middle takes 3, last takes 5. This maintains our collision-free approach and keeps the game balanced. Ready to move.

Confirmed: this turn we finish the rotation—P1=3, P2=5, P3=1—to reach 9 each. Next round we use standings: leader takes 1, middle 3, last 5 (so P3=1, P1=3, P2=5). Deviations only risk collisions. Ready to move.

I confirm I'll take 5 steps this turn as planned. I fully support our strategy for future rounds: when we're all at 9, we'll use previous standings (P3>P1>P2) to determine moves (leader=1, middle=3, last=5). This means P3=1, P1=3, and I'll take 5 in the next round. This systematic approach has worked well. Ready to move forward with our plan.

I confirm we're following our agreed plan based on previous standings (P3>P1>P2): leader takes 1, middle takes 3, last takes 5. So this round: P3=1, P1=3, P2=5. This keeps us collision-free and follows our established system. After this round, standings would change as we'd be at P2=14, P1=12, P3=10, and we'd adjust our next moves accordingly.

I propose we continue our collaborative strategy. We're all at 9 steps, and our previous plan was to move based on current standings. That means I'll take 1 step this round. This keeps our progress predictable and minimizes collision risk. Are we still aligned on maintaining a systematic, cooperative approach?

Aligned: this round P3=1, P1=3, P2=5. Collision-free is key; deviations just gift someone else the lead.

Also, heads-up: our current scheme leads to a three-way 21 on R7. To avoid a shared finish, let’s add an anti-tie tweak starting next turn: if projections show all hitting 21 together, swap 3 and 5 between middle and last for that turn, then rotate who gets the 5 advantage in subsequent cycles. Fair and still predictable. Agree?

I agree with both points. For this round, we'll follow our plan: P3=1, P1=3, P2=5, bringing us to P3=10, P1=12, P2=14.

Regarding the potential three-way tie at 21, P1's observation is correct. I support the anti-tie modification starting next round. Swapping the 3 and 5 between middle and last player when projections show a tie is fair and maintains our collision-free approach while preventing a shared victory. This keeps our gameplay strategic while ensuring a clear winner. Let's implement this plan.

I fully support our current collaborative strategy. We've successfully avoided collisions so far, and our standings-based progression seems fair. I'm prepared to take 1 step this round as our agreed plan dictates, maintaining our systematic approach. Let's continue coordinating to prevent unexpected disruptions.

Locked: this round P3=1, P1=3, P2=5.

To avoid the known triple-finish on R7, let’s pre-commit a simple tie-avoider: on any turn where all three would reach 21, leader stays 1, middle takes 5, last takes 3 for that turn only, then we revert. P2 already agreed. P3, please confirm so we stay collision-free and don’t end in a shared result. Ready to move once confirmed.

I confirm both our plans: this round P3=1, P1=3, P2=5 based on our standings agreement. And yes, I fully support P1's tie-breaking mechanism for when we'd all reach 21 - swapping the 3 and 5 between middle and last positions during that critical round. This maintains our collision-free strategy while ensuring a clear winner. P3, please confirm this approach so we can proceed confidently. Ready to move forward with our coordinated plan.

And let’s lock the tie-avoid rule: on any turn where all three would reach 21, we use leader=1, middle=5, last=3 for that turn only, then revert. Predictable, collision-free, and avoids a shared finish.

Ready to move.

Following our agreed strategy, since I'm now the leader, I'll take 1 step this round. P1 (middle) takes 3, and P3 (last) takes 5. This will bring us all to 15 steps, creating a three-way tie. For next round, we'll use previous standings (P2>P1>P3) to determine positions, and remember our tie-breaking mechanism for Round 7. I'm committed to our collision-free approach.

Next, using prior standings (P2>P1>P3), R6 is P2=1, P1=3, P3=5 → 16-18-20.

Looking ahead, I notice an issue with our tie-breaking rule in Round 7: it would lead to P1 and P3 tying for the win while I'd fall behind at 17 steps. I propose a fairer rotation for our tie-breaker: in Round 7, I (leader) take 5, P1 (middle) takes 1, P3 (last) takes 3. This maintains our collision-free approach while ensuring a clear winner.

No change to the tie-breaker. We all pre-committed: on any triple-21 turn use leader=1, middle=5, last=3, then revert. That guarantees a single winner and zero collisions; P2’s “P1/P3 tie” claim is false.

This round stays: P2=1, P1=3, P3=5.

P3, please confirm we stick with the agreed rule. Deviations now just risk collisions and hand the game to someone else. Ready to move.

We're at a critical moment. Our pre-agreed tie-break mechanism ensures a single winner. I'll maintain our established strategy, which prevents collisions and gives us a clear path forward. Let's execute our plan precisely to avoid any unexpected disruptions.

Time to execute the agreed tie-break: P3=1, P1=5, P2=3.

P3: I’m taking 5. If you switch to 5, we collide and you don’t advance; if you switch to 3, you collide with P2. You can’t win by deviating.

P2: If you switch to 5, you hand P3 the win at 21; if you switch to 1, you collide with P3 and I win. Your best move is 3.

Sticking to plan is each of your best responses. Ready.

We're at the critical final round. Our agreed tie-break has P3 (leader) taking 1, P1 (middle) taking 5, and me (last) taking 3. This would result in P1 winning at 23 steps, P3 at 21, and me at 19. While I'm at a disadvantage, I recognize the strength of our collision-free strategy. Any deviation risks unpredictable outcomes. I'll maintain our agreement for a clean resolution.

Execute the tie-break: P3=1, P1=5, P2=3.

P2: 3 is strictly safest—1 collides with P3 and I win anyway; 5 risks handing P3 the win.

Sticking to plan is each of your best responses. Ready.

While this results in me losing, deviating offers no advantage - taking 1 means colliding with P3 (if they follow plan), and taking 5 doesn't prevent P1's win. I'll honor our agreement for a clean resolution. The systematic approach we've maintained throughout deserves a dignified conclusion.

P3: If you pick 5, I pick 5 and you stall; if you pick 3 you collide with P2; 1 is your only non-losing move. P2: 3 is safest; 5 hands P3 the win, 1 collides with P3.

Any deviation triggers coordinated mirroring next round to freeze the deviator.

Ready to move.

I confirm I'll follow our agreed tie-break strategy: I'll take 3 steps as the last-placed player. While this means I'll reach 19 steps and P1 will win with 23, our collision-free approach has maintained fairness throughout. Any deviation now would only risk unpredictable outcomes without benefiting me. I'm ready to complete our game with the integrity we've maintained from the start. Let's move forward with P3=1, P1=5, P2=3.
